g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: Please select 'Start' from the main menu to begin
A transaction-based remote repository is used to maintain a database of employees
A remote copy of a G2 matrix is kept up to date in GSI via the item passing feature
Externally generated alarm objects are passed to G2 using item passing capability
Invocations of G2 procedures from within GSI via remote procedure call facility
Invocations of GSI functions from within G2 via remote procedure call facility
Data service to registered G2 variables with GSI's attribute value return capability
Data service of simple data types to G2 variables which are registered (mapped) to external data points
Please press the button that corresponds with the GSI example you wish to explore

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

This is an example application (maintaining a database of employees) of an example application (a transaction-based multi-user remote repository).
The repository maintains the 'original' of any object it is given. G2 instances of repository objects are copies. Modifications to these copies are automatically sent to the repository where the original is updated and where the changes are broadcast to any clients who are 'watching' the updated object. A G2 client may 'watch' a repository object, in which case changes originating in other G2s are automatically reflected in the local copy.

To add a new employee, fill out the template, and enter the employee's name in the New employee type-in box. This will add an object to the repository but no local copy is kept. To get a local copy (to watch this new employee), enter the employee's name in the Watch employee type-in box.
To test the watch feature, run this example in another G2 connecting to the same repository, watch the same employee from both G2s and you will see that modifying the employee in one G2 updates the copy in the other G2.

g2:c.RULE.g2:a.TEXT: whenever any parameter P that is an attribute of any generic-r-object receives a value and when repository-modifications-enabled then start r-mod-wrapper(the value of name-of-target, the attribute-name of P, the value of P)

g2:c.REMOTE-PROCEDURE-DECLARATION.g2:a.TEXT: declare remote r-snapshot (integer) = ((class repository-object including the system attributes : current value of variable-or-parameter, name of item, history of variable-or-parameter), symbol)
declare remote r-watch-object (integer, (class repository-object as handle) ) = (symbol)
declare remote r-add-object (class repository-object including the system attributes : current value of variable-or-parameter, name of item, history of variable-or-parameter) = (integer)

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: r-mod-wrapper(target-name: symbol, attribute-name : symbol, mod: value) status: symbol; begin if the repository-object named by target-name exists and the repository-tag of the repository-object named by target-name /= -1 then status = call r-modify(the repository-object named by target-name, attribute-name, mod) else start log-message ("The object name specified ([target-name]) does not correspond to a watched repository object. You must be 'watching' a repository object in order to modify it."); end
r-remove(tag: integer) begin call r-remove-object(tag) across repository-interface; end

g2:c.RULE.g2:a.TEXT: whenever name-of-target receives a value and when the r-employee named by name-of-target exists then start update-generic-employee(the r-employee named by name-of-target)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: To create a new GSI example, clone one of the examples to the left, modify it to suit your needs, and clone one of the action buttons on STARTUP replacing the example name with that which you create here.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

In this example the GSI process maintains a matrix (array) of floating point numbers. Every time you change Value, the number you specified is enterred into G2's copy of the matrix, and the current value of Index is added to a list G2 maintains. Every time you press Update-remote-matrix, G2 sends its copy to GSI along with the list of indices where changes have occurred since the last update, and the index list is cleared.
GSI updates its matrix and displays the contents each time it receives an update from G2.

g2:c.RULE.g2:a.TEXT: whenever float-matrix-value receives a value then start update-change-list (float-matrix-index) and conclude that float-matrix [float-matrix-index] = float-matrix-value

g2:c.REMOTE-PROCEDURE-DECLARATION.g2:a.TEXT: declare remote update-remote-matrix ( (class float-array including the system attribute name of item), ( class integer-list including the system attribute name of item)) = (symbol)

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.
Pressing Enable-alarming causes GSI to begin sending the same dummy alarm object once a second to G2. Disable-alarming causes GSI to stop.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Enable Alarming
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: conclude that alarm-x-pos = starting-x-pos and conclude that alarm-y-pos = starting-y-pos and start enable-alarming() across alarmer-interface

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Delete alarms
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: delete every alarm and conclude that alarm-x-pos = starting-x-pos and conclude that alarm-y-pos = starting-y-pos

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
This test has nothing to do with file access but the code to support this test is within the sources for filetest.
When the Invoke Call button pressed, a string will be sent via the "inform" action to the gsi_receive_message() function within filetest.c. This function in turn calls the G2 procedure on this workspace which posts a message to the message board and returns to a receiving function in the C code.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Invoke Call
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: inform sample-gsi-variable that "call a G2 procedure from GSI."

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: G2-TEST-PROCEDURE ( x : quantity , y: text, z : symbol ) = (quantity, text, symbol) begin start log-message("Received a message of length [x] from GSI via remote procedure call. Message: [y] Also received the symbol [z]."); return the current time , y, z; end

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: When the workspace is activated, press the copy button to copy the filename specified by the fname attribute of testrfile (which must be in the format of the graphics.dat file supplied on the G2 tape) to the filename specified by the fname attribute of testwfile. The GSI bridge typetest does not support modifications to the remote procedure declarations.

g2:c.REMOTE-PROCEDURE-DECLARATION.g2:a.TEXT: declare remote write (integer, integer, integer, integer, integer, integer, integer, symbol) = (integer)
declare remote read (integer, integer, integer) = (integer,integer,integer, integer, integer, symbol)

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Write
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start write-file (testwfile, 4, 1, the startx of testrfile, the endx of testrfile, the starty of testrfile, the endy of testrfile, the type of testrfile)

g2:c.PROCEDURE.g2:a.TEXT: cancel-simple-dialog() begin conclude that dialog-status is cancelled; end
okay-simple-dialog() begin conclude that dialog-status is okayed; end

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
The "main" value of each vector represents the status of the file (good or eof). The values in a vectors attributes represent one record's worth of data from the file. The filename is specified by the gsi-interface's remote process initialization string (a sample file, "graphics.dat", is distributed with GSI). With multiple registered vectors reading out of the same file, the end of the file will be reached more quickly.
Note, that the use of multiple interfaces to one GSI process demonstrates the GSI ability to support multiple contexts.

When this example starts, the workspace is activated, and vector-2 should begin receiving values through attribute-return-interface. Vector-3 and vectors 4 and 5 will begin receiving values through attribute-return-interface-2 and attribute-return-interface-3 respectively when the latter are enabled (click on vector object and select enable option).

g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.LABEL: Disconnect
g2:c.ACTION-BUTTON.g2:a.ACTION: start disconnect(the gsi-example superior to this workspace)

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT:
If the GSI image is running on the same host as this G2 and is listening at the default TCP/IP port number, connection should occur automatically.
If not, please adjust the GSI connection configuration of the GSI interface to correspond with the network address of the GSI image. The network information printed at startup by the image may be used for this purpose. The status display to the lower right of the interface should equal 2 when properly connected.

g2:c.RULE.g2:a.TEXT: unconditionally set string_dat to "The quick brown fox jumped the tall black fence"
unconditionally set string_dat to "CHICKEN SOUP IS GOOD FOR YOU !!!!!"
unconditionally set symbol_dat to the symbol The.quick.brown.coyote.killed.the.rabbit
unconditionally set symbol_dat to the symbol ARUBA.jamaica.STCROIX.tortola
unconditionally set integer_dat to the current time * (-1)
unconditionally set float64_dat to the current time + 0.246

g2:c.BORDERLESS-FREE-TEXT.g2:a.TEXT: When this example starts, the workspace is activated, the data transmittal rules fire, calling gsi_set_data() within typetest which stores away the values being set for each gsi-variable. GSI-data-seeking calls gsi_get_data() within typetest and polling from the gsi interface object calls gsi_g2_poll(), both of which return the stored values to the appropriate gsi-variable.

g2:c.RULE.g2:a.TEXT: whenever the gsi-interface-status of the gsi-interface I upon the subworkspace of any gsi-example X receives a value then start launch(X)
initially show startup with its top left corner at the top left corner of the screen and show reset with its top right corner at the top right corner of the screen and hide welcome
